channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine News: Russia Calls E.U. Move to Advance Ukraine’s Joining ‘Hostile’
item.description: The decision, which sets Ukraine on a probably lengthy path toward becoming a member of the bloc, signals more resistance to Putin. Russian forces advanced on a key eastern city, threatening its supply lines.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Need for Aid Is Critical in Afghanistan After Devastating Earthquake
item.description: New York Times journalists talked to residents in the hardest-hit part of southeastern Afghanistan who were seeking help and beginning to reckon with their losses.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: How an Abortion Ban Trapped a Tourist on Malta
item.description: Andrea Prudente, an American, developed pregnancy complications while on the island that could put her life at risk. But abortion is illegal there, and she is seeking a safe way to leave.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Demonstrating against Malta’s ban on abortion, outside Parliament House in the capital, Valletta, on Wednesday.

item.title: South Africa’s Corruption Inquiry Leaves Few of the Nation’s Powerful Unscathed
item.description: The final portion of a three-year investigation reported graft on a massive scale under former President Jacob Zuma, but also found the current president’s actions wanting.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, right, receives the final investigation report from Chief Justice Raymond Zondo at the government's Union Buildings in Pretoria on Wednesday.

item.title: Russian Elites Show No Sign of Broad Challenge to Putin
item.description: Many business owners and intellectuals fled Russia after the invasion of Ukraine, but others stayed behind, struggling to redefine their lives. Their diverging choices do not add up to a broad challenge to Vladimir Putin’s war.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Kremlin in Moscow in February. Russians who stayed after the invasion have taken differing paths in responding to the war.

item.title: Extreme Weather Hits China With Massive Floods and Scorching Heat
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people have been displaced by the historic flooding. Elsewhere, record-high temperatures are rupturing roads and driving energy consumption.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: A flooded area after heavy rains in Shangrao, in Jiangxi Province in southeastern China.

item.title: Pope Francis Will Visit Canada for Apology Despite Health Issues
item.description: Francis plans to deliver a long-sought apology to Indigenous people for the church’s role in a residential school system where abuse was rife.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Wednesday. Knee problems had caused the postponement of an African trip this month.

item.title: Iran Dismisses Revolutionary Guards’ Powerful Intelligence Chief
item.description: Hossein Taeb, a top official in the force, was transferred to a lower ranking job amid an escalation in Israel’s shadow war with Iran.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Hamed Malekpour/Tasnim News, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hossein Taeb, a Shiite cleric and head of the intelligence for the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, at a meeting in the capital Tehran in 2018.

item.title: In South Africa’s Farmgate Scandal, a Theft and Then a Silence
item.description: Namibian investigators tracing money transfers by men suspected of stealing wads of cash from President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa say their cross-border calls for help went unanswered.
item.dc:creator: Tileni Mongudhi and John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, right, campaigning before local elections last year. This year, he is in the thick of a battle to be re-elected as leader of his party.

item.title: Saudi Prince Visits Turkey For First Time Since Khashoggi Murder
item.description: The 2018 killing and dismemberment of the Saudi dissident and journalist Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents in Istanbul drove a deep wedge between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Safak Timur
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, right, on Wednesday with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on his first visit to Turkey since the murder of the Saudi dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents in Istanbul in 2018.

item.title: Analysis: What Turkey Wants to Let Finland and Sweden Into NATO
item.description: Finnish and Swedish hopes of being accepted as applicants by next week’s NATO summit meeting have been dashed by a Turkish government that says it is in no hurry.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Finnish soldiers during NATO military exercises this month on an island in the Baltic Sea.

item.title: Mykolaiv Keeps Defying Russia’s Attacks on Ukraine’s Black Sea Coast
item.description: Without its Black Sea coast, a landlocked Ukraine would struggle. Mykolaiv is determined that won’t happen.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Svetlaya, 67, whose home in Mykolaiv, Ukraine, was hit on Friday.

item.title: China’s Surveillance State Is Growing. These Documents Reveal How.
item.description: A New York Times analysis of over 100,000 government bidding documents found that China’s ambition to collect digital and biological data from its citizens is more expansive and invasive than previously known.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Paul Mozur, Isabelle Qian and Alexander Cardia

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine’s E.U. candidacy.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian flags flying alongside E.U. flags yesterday in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: First Step Toward Ukraine Joining E.U. Signals Solidarity Amid War
item.description: As Russia’s brutal offensive squeezes defenders in eastern Ukraine, Europe’s leaders, in a rebuke to Moscow, made a move they would have rejected before the invasion.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Four soldiers wounded in an artillery strike were dropped off at a bus stop-turned-aid station, where awaiting medics quickly went about stabilizing them on Thursday in Bakhmut, Ukraine.

item.title: Ecuador Roiled by Protests Set Off by Rising Fuel and Food Prices
item.description: The country’s capital has been virtually paralyzed by demonstrators, and the government says it has lost control of a small city in the Amazon to protesters wielding guns, spears and explosives.
item.dc:creator: José María León Cabrera and Megan Janetsky
item.media:description: A protester throwing a tear gas canister at police officers on Wednesday in Quito.

item.title: U.S. Announces $450 Million More in Military Aid for Ukraine
item.description: The latest announcement brings the total amount of military aid from the United States to Ukraine to $6.8 billion since the beginning of the Biden administration.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: The United States will send four more truck-mounted rocket launchers, called the M142 HIMARS — for High Mobility Artillery Rocket System — to Ukraine.

item.title: In Afghan Quake: ‘I Did Not Expect to Survive’
item.description: As aid workers and volunteers rushed to help, survivors told harrowing tales of death and destruction.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah, Kyle Crichton and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hawa and her daughter Safia, at the hospital in Sharana, in Afghanistan’s Paktika province, on Thursday. Four of Hawa’s children and 17 other family members perished in the quake.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: After the Quake
item.description: Afghans search for survivors and China faces twin extreme weather crises.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Padshah Gun (30) outside of where used to be his house in Azor Kalai village of Geyun district. From 19 members of his family, 16 survived the earthquake.

item.title: Eurovision Defends Not Allowing Ukraine to Host 2023 Contest
item.description: Eurovision officials cited the need to guarantee the security of all those involved in the contest, robbing Ukraine, this year’s winner, of the chance to be an international showcase.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The frontman of Kalush Orchestra, Oleh Psiuk, center, signed an open letter to Eurovision organizers demanding the reversal of their decision to not hold the 2023 edition of the contest in Ukraine.

item.title: Origin of the Monkeypox Outbreak Becomes Clearer to Scientists
item.description: Even as cases rise, genetic analysis suggests that the virus has been silently circulating in people since 2018.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: People wait in line at a monkeypox vaccination clinic in Montreal, in June.

item.title: When, Exactly, Did Mount Vesuvius Erupt?
item.description: From tracing ashes to Greece to analyzing autumnal fruit found in Pompeii, a new study places the eruption in October, not August.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Roberto Salomone for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pompeii archeological site, in February.

item.title: Austria Quietly Discards Covid-19 Vaccine Mandate that It Never Enforced
item.description: The mandate threatened fines for adults who chose not to be vaccinated, but the government held off enforcement after a panel determined that the Omicron variant was less of a threat than Delta.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Workers processing a shipment of coronavirus vaccines in Salzburg, Austria, in January.

item.title: In Remote Afghanistan, Scenes From a Deadly Earthquake
item.description: Officials said hopes of finding additional survivors were fading as they worked to bring aid to the injured in Paktika Province.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Biden Administration Tosses Trump Definition of ‘Habitat’ for Endangered Species
item.description: The Trump administration’s definition was at odds with the conservation purposes of the Endangered Species Act, wildlife officials said.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: A manatee in the Homosassa River in Florida, where conservationists had planted sea grass to help restore the animal’s feeding grounds.

item.title: Deborah Birx Says Trump White House Asked Her to Weaken Covid Guidance
item.description: The former White House coronavirus coordinator, who became a controversial figure, said there was a consistent effort to stifle information as virus cases surged in late 2020.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Deborah L. Birx, President Donald J. Trump’s coronavirus response coordinator, told a congressional panel on Thursday that the Trump administration’s attitude toward the coronavirus had caused a “false sense of security in America.”

item.title: In a stricken village in Paktika, ‘Everyone here cried from night to morning.’
item.dc:creator: Najim Rahim
item.media:description: Damaged homes in Gayan, in Afghanistan’s Paktika Province, on Thursday.

item.title: Russia is crimping gas flows just as Europe is racing to stock up for winter.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: An underground natural gas storage facility in Rehden, Germany.

item.title: The Mental Toll of the War in Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainians are trying to confront the war’s psychological wounds even as the battles wear on.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: A destroyed building in Lysychansk, near neighboring Sievierodonetsk. Bombing continued between Russian and Ukrainian forces here, where a majority of the population has fled.

item.title: Biden’s Inner Circle Debates Future of Offshore Drilling
item.description: Top White House officials have assumed control over a sensitive blueprint, expected by June 30, laying out future oil and gas drilling leases in the outer continental shelf.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden hosted the Major Economies Forum on Energy and Climate from the White House last week.

item.title: A Gay Pilot Reflects on What Travel Means to Queer Folks
item.description: As Pride is celebrated around the world, a traveler recalls the cities that helped shape his identity and dreams.
item.dc:creator: Mark Vanhoenacker

item.title: European Leaders Meet to Decide on Granting Ukraine E.U. Candidate Status
item.description: Their approval would allow Ukraine to be a candidate to join the bloc, starting what could be a long road.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: The leaders of Romania, Italy, France and Germany expressed support for granting Ukraine candidate status for admission into the European Union in Kyiv last week.

item.title: As Russia Fortifies Ukrainian Nuclear Plant, Workers Flee Repression, Officials Say
item.description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, Europe’s largest, lies in southern Ukraine in a strategically important spot.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A photograph taken during a trip organized by the Russian military showed a Russian serviceman near the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Station in Enerhodar, Ukraine, in May.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine’s president addresses African leaders.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Sacks of wheat flour at the Hamar-Weyne market in Mogadishu, Somalia, last month.

item.title: A study of the war details Russia’s many failed cyberattacks, but also its power in disinformation.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin with Russia’s defense minister, Sergei Shoigu, at a wreath-laying ceremony at Moscow’s Tomb of the Unknown Soldier on Wednesday.

item.title: As the war grinds on, U.S. lawmakers press for better military assessments of allies’ will to fight.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Defense officials have acknowledged misjudging the Ukrainian military’s ability to stand up against Russian invaders.

item.title: Russia Gains in Eastern Ukraine, Threatening to Overrun Luhansk
item.description: The seizure of three strategic villages confronts Ukrainian commanders with a grim choice: fight on and risk encirclement or retreat and lose the last major centers in the region.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Ukrainian service members in Sievierodonetsk, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Devastating Afghanistan Earthquake Leaves More Than 1,000 Dead
item.description: The quake — the deadliest in the country in two decades — was the latest in a string of tragedies to affect the country since the Taliban seized power from the U.S.-backed government last summer.
item.dc:creator: Safiullah Padshah, Alissa J. Rubin and Mike Ives

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Deadly Earthquake in Afghanistan
item.description: Also, a pivotal showdown looms in Eastern Ukraine and China squeezes Taiwan’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Bakhtar News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Some of the destruction in the province of Paktika, in eastern Afghanistan.

item.title: Businessman Tied to China Alibaba Rape Case Gets 18 Months
item.description: A court found Zhang Guo guilty of “forcible indecency.” The tech giant fired his accuser last year after she claimed that he had molested her and that her boss had raped her.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: The incident attracted national attention last year when the woman, known by only her surname, Zhou, screamed about it at an Alibaba cafeteria.

item.title: ‘Not in This for the Money’: Why Some Families Sue North Korea
item.description: Families whose relatives have been abducted or imprisoned by North Korea are seeking to hold the country financially accountable despite the long odds of collecting money from the isolated nation.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Choi Byung-hee, whose father was abducted by North Korea, holding the only picture she has of him. She is seated with her aunt and uncle (and her father’s siblings): Choi Cha-moon, 86, left, and Choi Tae-boon, 79, at Mr. Choi’s home in Seoul in June.

item.title: Kaliningrad Is Again a Flash Point in East-West Relations
item.description: Wedged between Poland and Lithuania and bristling with missiles capable of flinging conventional or nuclear warheads into Europe, Kaliningrad has become emblematic of the Cold War era.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kaliningrad’s House of Soviets was never fully occupied but still towers over the remains of the Prussian Königsberg Castle, which the Soviet authorities demolished in the 1960s.

item.title: When Gun Violence Outrage Isn’t Enough to Bring Reform
item.description: An examination of crises in the Americas — including school shootings in the U.S. — yields a sobering theory about why even a national outpouring of pain cannot always overcome political divides.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police in São Paulo, Brazil, in 2020.

item.title: A pivotal showdown approaches in eastern Ukraine as more villages fall to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ukrainian tanks and military vehicles heading toward the village of Toshkivka on Sunday.

item.title: A Pro-Religion Court
item.description: What the 6-3 conservative Supreme Court majority’s latest ruling means.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court in Washington.

item.title: Finding New Route for Ukraine’s Grain Exports Isn’t So Simple
item.description: Proposed alternatives include exporting into Poland or transporting it into Romania and out through the Black Sea port of Constanta.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A storage facility for grain in Boryspil, Ukraine. World leaders are working to find new solutions for exporting Ukraine’s agricultural products.

item.title: Boris Johnson Risks a Sharp Rebuke in U.K. By-Elections
item.description: Scandals, economic pain and an uproar over lockdown parties have left Britain’s Conservatives at risk of losing both recent advances and old strongholds.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Simon Lightwood, center, is the leading opposition candidate in Wakefield, where a member of Parliament for Britain’s governing Conservatives resigned after a sexual assault conviction.

item.title: How Sabyasachi Made the Sari Haute
item.description: As his country’s most famous designer, Sabyasachi has persuaded Indians to see the luxury in their fashion heritage. Can he persuade Americans too?
item.dc:creator: Francesca Mari
item.media:credit: Zishaan A Latif for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sabyasachi at home in Kolkata.

item.title: The Netrebko Question
item.description: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko is opera’s biggest star. But her career is in disarray because of her ties to Putin, and arts companies around the world are divided on whether to welcome her back.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández

item.title: Funerals in Lviv Show Growing Toll of Ukraine’s War
item.description: The funeral for a marine who loved the sport of parachuting was the first of four on Tuesday for local soldiers killed in heavy fighting against Russia in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners prayed and sang during Artemiy Dymyd’s funeral at the Lychakiv cemetery in Lviv, Ukraine, on Tuesday. Mr. Dymyd was killed in battle while serving in a special operation unit of the Ukrainian marines.

item.title: Ukrainian Black Sea Strikes Suggest Arrival of Western Weapons, Analysts Say
item.description: The Ukrainian military said it was attacking Russian infrastructure on Snake Island.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainian weapons hit Snake Island, off the coast of Odesa, as well as a former natural gas rig where Russian forces had placed radio-jamming equipment, a former top defense official said.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Asia buys up Russian oil.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Oil tanks at a crude oil terminal near the port city of Nakhodka, Russia, this month.

item.title: Companies Brace for Impact of New Forced Labor Law
item.description: Billions of dollars could be at stake as a law banning imports of some products from China goes into effect.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Container ships waiting to enter the Port of Los Angeles last year. Enforcement of a new law could lead the U.S. authorities to detain or turn away a multitude of imported products.

item.title: The U.S. confirms the death of an American presumed to be the second killed on the battlefield in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim

item.title: A shopping trip for apples, over the last bridge in Lysychansk.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: How Russia Is Making More in Oil Sales Now Than Before the War
item.description: With China and India buying the Russian oil shunned by the West in an effort to force an end to the Ukraine invasion, Moscow is earning more now than it did before the war.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim, Clifford Krauss and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A Lukoil refinery in Volgograd, Russia.

item.title: As Russia renews shelling in Kharkiv, the civilian death toll is growing, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:description: A destroyed building in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukrainian civilians return to cities that bear the scars of war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
